title: Global warming
intro: What might the world look like if the temperature keeps rising? There will be many losers – but who are the likely winners? Neil and Alice discuss what we need to do to adapt to the inevitable changes ahead.
this_week_question: How much has the average temperature of the Earth's surface increased in the last hundred years? Is it…
You'll hear the answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: not normal for the time of year
removing the salt and other minerals from sea water homegrown produced locally cost-efficient good value for the money you paid logistics the organization of a complex activity

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Alice…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. I'm feeling a bit chilly today, Alice.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, it is unseasonably cold today – which means not normal for the time of year. But the weather is very unpredictable these days.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I know what you mean.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, global warming is the subject of today's show.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Is global warming really something to worry about? Some people say that the Earth has warmed up in the past and nothing terrible has happened.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: The Earth has warmed up before, but this was the result of things like wobbles in the Earth's orbit, not because of an increase of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Can we reverse the changes?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, it's too late, and now we have to find ways to adapt to extreme weather, rising sea levels, and melting polar ice caps. However, we can mitigate greenhouse gas emissions – or make them less harmful. But before we talk more about this, I have a question for you. How much has the average temperature of the Earth's surface increased in the last hundred years? Is it… a) 0.85°C? b) 1.85°C? Or c) 8.5°C?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm gonna go for the big one a) 8.5°C.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out if you got the answer right later on, Neil. But first, do you know any ways to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I do, actually. An Argentinian company has started collecting cow… emissions and converting them into usable energy.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, as the world eats more meat, methane emissions from livestock are actually becoming a bigger climate concern.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And one day's worth of cow emissions provides energy to run a car for 24 hours.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: OK, moving on now, so the world is going to have to adapt to global warming since we can't turn back the clock on climate change. And rich countries have the resources to do this, whilst poorer countries don't. Let's hear from Saleemul Huq, Director of the International Centre for Climate Change and Development in Bangladesh, talking about how this problem is being addressed.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Saleemul Huq, Director, International Centre for Climate Change and Development in Bangladesh Saleemul Huq: The rich countries have already pledged and promised a hundred billion dollars a year, starting from 2020, to cover all kinds of climate change activities which in climate change are either going to be called mitigation or adaptation. Owen Bennett Jones: A year? But that's an enormous sum of money! Saleemul Huq: Not that enormous compared to what they gave to the banking system when it collapsed. Climate change is a much bigger problem than the banking crisis.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Saleemul Huq interviewed on the BBC World Service programme Newshour Extra. Well, he says rich countries have pledged – or promised – to deliver a hundred billion dollars a year to help poorer countries adapt to climate change. However, he suggests that this sum could have been larger – since more money than this was donated to resolve the banking crisis.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: For example, after the devastating effects of Hurricane Sandy, New York City invested ten billion dollars on storm defences to protect Manhattan – and Wall Street.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And where lack of water is a problem, countries like Australia, China, and Spain, have built desalination plants, which remove the salt from seawater to produce drinking water. But it's too expensive for developing countries to do this, even though they need them.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: So in relative terms, one billion dollars a year to help poor countries is a small sum of money when compared to their need. Countries like Bangladesh have developed homegrown technologies – which means produced locally – such as harvesting rainwater from their rooftops.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Alice, and thinking about certain radical proposals for adaptation – did you know there's a Dutch company that wants to build floating cities for us to live in?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, I didn't.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah. Plans include 15-storey high-rise buildings and floating food production.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It sounds like it would be incredibly expensive. Has anyone actually built one?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: No, not so far. Let's hear from Mark Maslin, Professor of Climatology at University College London, talking about why this might be.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Mark Maslin, Professor of Climatology at University College London Remember, we're going to have 9.5 billion people by the middle of this century. Now, if you think about it, think about the logistics of building a city, floating, for say, ten million people. And then multiply that up to 60 per cent of 9.5 billion people. OK? So don't think it's really cost-efficient.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So in practical terms, the logistics of building a large floating city probably couldn't work. It wouldn't be cost-efficient – or good value for the money you paid.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And logistics means the organization of a complex activity.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: On the other hand, the logistics of teaching farmers in Bangladesh to breed ducks instead of chickens, for example, would be relatively simple and cost-efficient – and since ducks float and chickens don't, it's a sensible adaptation to climate change!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: That's a great example, Neil! Now, I think it's time for the answer to today's quiz question. I asked: How much has the average temperature of the Earth's surface increased in the last hundred years? Is it… a) 0.85°C, b) 1.85°C or c) 8.5°C?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said c) 8.5°C and I know I'm wrong.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes, I'm afraid you are Neil. The right answer is actually 0.85°C. And did you know that 13 of the 14 warmest years were recorded in the 21st Century?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I did not know that, Alice. But I do know which words we learned today. They are: unseasonably mitigate pledged desalination homegrown cost-efficient logistics

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: And that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Don't forget to join us again soon!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
